block.p: Emboldened by the early success of its latest cease-fire in Yugoslavia, the European Community decided today to step up the work of its faltering peace conference in The Hague.

The Netherlands, which holds the rotating presidency of the community, announced that three major leaders from Yugoslavia would travel to The Hague on Thursday for a meeting with Hans van den Broek, the Dutch Foreign Minister. They are the Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic; the President of the Croatian republic, Franjo Tudjman; and Veljko Kadijevic, the Yugoslav Defense Minister.
Emboldened by the early success of its latest cease-fire in Yugoslavia, the European Community decided today to step up the work of its faltering peace conference in The Hague.

The Netherlands, which holds the rotating presidency of the community, announced that three major leaders from Yugoslavia would travel to The Hague on Thursday for a meeting with Hans van den Broek, the Dutch Foreign Minister. They are the Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic; the President of the Croatian republic, Franjo Tudjman; and Veljko Kadijevic, the Yugoslav Defense Minister.
On Monday at The Hague there is to be a session of the peace conference attended by representatives of all 6 Yugoslav republics and the 12 members of the European Community.
